AN ORDINANCE
AMENDING THE
THE PLEASANT GARDEN CODE OF GENERAL ORDINANCES
AND
THE PLEASANT GARDEN ZONING ORDINANCE
TO COMBINE THE ZONING AND LONG-RANGE PLANNING BOARDS
AND MAKE OTHER CORRECTIVE AMENDMENTS
WHEREAS, by previous enactment in the Pleasant Garden Code of General Ordinances,
§ 3-44 (a)-(c) creates and describes the functions of a Zoning Board, and § 3-44(a)-(c)
creates and describes the functions of a Long-Range Planning Board; and,
WHEREAS, by previous enactment in the Pleasant Garden Development Ordinance,
§ 2-1.1(A) defines and § 9-2 creates and describes the functions of a Zoning Board, and §
2-1.1(B) defines and § 9-3 creates and describes the functions of a Long-Range Planning
Board, respectively, each such board being therein created and empowered as to
functions pursuant to former N.C. Gen. Stat., 160A-361, now N.C. Gen. Stat. §§ 160D-
301; and,
WHEREAS, the authority for the creation and empowering of such boards is delegated by
the General Assembly solely though the provisions of Chapter 160D (formerly, Chapter
160A, Article 19) of the North Carolina General Statutes, and the enactment and
codification of the foregoing general ordinance provisions are hereby deemed improvident
and duplicative, and should be repealed as a matter of clarity and simplifying the Pleasant
Garden ordinances; and,
WHEREAS, and furthermore, it is the opinion of the Town Council that participation in and
the effectiveness of long-range planning will be enhanced if the functions of zoning and
long-range planning are combined in the Development Ordinance into one planning body
under the authority of N.C. Gen. Stat. §§ 160D-301, by eliminating the separate Longe-
Range Planning Board, adding the duties thereof to those assigned to the Zoning Board,
and renaming the Zoning Board the "Planning Board"; and,
WHEREAS, and furthermore, in the enactment of amendments to the Pleasant Garden
Development Ordinance to make said ordinance provisions compliant with Chapter 160D
as mandated by the General Assembly, it now appears that the reenactment of the prior
provisions describing the powers and duties of the Zoning Board was improvident and
should have been replaced with the amended description thereof in N.C. Gen. Stat. §
160D-301(d), as set forth below, and which encompasses the combined duties of zoning
and long-range planning boards as herein intended;
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED:
Section 1. That § 3-44(a)-(c) and § 3-44(a)-(c), respectively, of the Pleasant Garden
Code of General Ordinances, are hereby repealed and said sections reserved.

Section 2. That § 9-2 of the Pleasant Garden Development Ordinance is hereby
amended and rewritten as follows:
9-2. - THE PLANNING ZONING BOARD
9-2.1. - Authority.
There is hereby created a planning agency, pursuant to N.C.G.S. § § 160D-301 and
160D-604 to be known as the Planning Zoning Board.
9-2.2. - Membership.
The Planning Zoning Board shall consist of at least five members appointed by the
Town Council.
9-2.3. - Powers and duties.
The Zoning Board has the following powers and duties:
(A) To hear and make recommendations concerning matters in accordance with the
terms of this Ordinance; to wit: zoning map amendments and zoning vested
rights;
(B)
To hear and decide on matters pertaining to road name changes, road closings,
right of way vacations, easement removals, right of way encroachments, and
watershed matters as assigned;
(C) To provide recommendations to the Town Council with regard to any of the above
matters whichmay be appealed; as well as those matters which remain with the
Town Council as original jurisdiction such as text amendments and minor
watershed modifications;
(D)
To review and approve new or altered plans including: subdivisions, attached
residential development, office, commercial, and industrial developments, street
and utility improvements, and any other proposals for development specified by
this Ordinance and waivers authorized in Article V (Subdivision: Procedures and
Standards);
(E) To exercise other powers and authority provided to it by the Town Council, this
Ordinance, or State law.
(Amend. of 1-7-2014)
The Planning Board has the following powers and duties:
(A) To prepare, review, maintain, monitor, and periodically update and recommend to the
Town Council a comprehensive plan, and such other plans as deemed appropriate, and
conduct ongoing related research, data collection, mapping, and analysis.
(B) To facilitate and coordinate citizen engagement and participation in the planning
process.

(C) To develop and recommend policies, ordinances, development regulations,
administrative procedures, and other means for carrying out plans in a coordinated and
efficient manner.
(D) To advise the Town Council concerning the implementation of plans, including, but not
limited to, review and comment on all zoning text and map amendments as required by
G.S. 160D-604.
(E) To exercise any functions in the administration and enforcement of various means for
carrying out plans that the Town Council may direct.
(F) To provide a preliminary forum for review of quasi-judicial decisions, provided that no
part of the forum or recommendation may be used as a basis for the deciding board.
(G) To make recommendations on overall planning and community development to the
Planning and Zoning Board and/or Town Council after careful research;
(H) To develop consensus among Town voters as to major changes in Municipal
services and Towndevelopment;
(I) To conduct continuing reviews of trends in population, crime, demand for various
services, and other community statistics both within the Town and in neighboring
communities;
(J) To maintain contact with other governments and organizations that can provide helpful
information or which may have an impact on the Town;
(K) To conduct surveys of Town residents and make periodic reports to residents, the
Zoning Board, and the Town Council on trends and issues likely to affect the Town in future
years and/or opportunities to enhance the quality of life for residents in future years;
(L) To make such other studies and plans and review such other related matters as
directed by the Town Council;
(M) To exercise any other power and authority provided to it by the Town Council, this
Ordinance, and State law;
(N) To serve as the Historic Preservation Commission as provided in Section 9-4.2 until
such time the Town Council determines otherwise; and,
(O) To perform any other related duties that the Town Council may direct.
Section 3. That, in order to make them consistent with the foregoing Section 2, the
following provisions of the Pleasant Garden Development Ordinance are hereby amended
as follows:
2-1.1. - Administration.
(A) Planning Zoning-Board. A body appointed by the Town Council that is given certain
powers under this Ordinancein accordance with Section 9-2.
(B) Long-Range Planning Board. A body appointed by the Town Council that is given certain

powers under this Ordinance in accordance with Section 3.3. Repealed.
2-1.5. - Easements.
(AV) Landfill, land clearing and inert debris (LCID) (minor). A disposal site that meets all
of the following conditions:
1) The fill material consists of debris strictly limited to concrete, brick, concrete
block, uncontaminated soil, rock, gravel, limbs, leaves, and stumps. Disposal of
any other types of wastes must be approved by the State Division of Solid Waste
Management; and
2)
The fill activity will cover two acres or less, be in operation three years or less,
provided that the Planning Zoning Board may upon request grant one or more
three-year renewals, and have direct access to a State-maintained paved road,
provided that the Planning Zoning-Board may grant a waiver to the paving
requirement upon reasonable conditions.
3-11.2. - Submission of site plans.
(A) Timing. Site plans for review by the Planning Zoning-Board shall be submitted to the
Planning Department of the Enforcement Officer at least 21 days prior to the next
scheduled meeting.
3-11.4. - Site plan and plot plan approval.
(A) Approval of site/plot plan. The site plan or plot plan shall be approved when it meets
all requirements of this Ordinance or proper waivers and/or variances are obtained.
(B) Approval authority.
1) Minor site plans submitted for developments, or additions to existing
developments, of less than 15,000 square feet of gross floor area, but not more
than eight dwelling units in a single building; or for open uses of land, or
expansions of open uses of land, involving less than 40,000 square feet; will be
reviewed by the Enforcement Officer and will be scheduled for a hearing by the Zoning
Board.
2) Major site plans submitted for developments, or additions to existing
developments, with 15,000squa feet or more of gross floor area; or for open
uses of land, or expansions of open uses of land involving 40,000 square feet or
more; will be reviewed by appropriate County staff for advisory comment before
forwarding to the Town Planning-Zoning Board and will be scheduled for a
hearing by the Planning Zoning-Board and ultimately the Town Council.
3)
Accessory structures of fewer than 400 square feet proposed for sites with an
approved site plan will be reviewed by the Enforcement Officer and may be
approved in consultation with the TownClerk.
(C) Voting.
1)
Applications receiving a majority favorable vote from the Planning Zoning Board
members present and voting shall constitute approval.
2)
Applications receiving less than a majority vote from the Planning Zoning-Board

members present and voting shall constitute denial. The applicant may appeal the
decision, and the application shall bescheduled for a hearing by the Town Council
or the applicant may revise the site plan for resubmittal.
3)
Under appeal, applications shall require a simple majority vote by the Town
Council to be approved.
(D) Action by Planning Zoning-Board. If a site plan is approved by the Planning Zoning
Board, the applicant may proceed with other requirements necessary to obtain a
building permit. If the Planning Zoning-Board denies a minor or major site plan,
reasons for the denial shall be stated in writing and the site plan may be revised and
resubmitted. The Planning Zoning Board shall take action within 30 days of reviewing
the site plan. If the site plan is denied or granted conditional approval, or if no action
is taken within 30 days by the Planning Zoning Board, the applicant may appeal the
site plan to the Town Council. The appeal may be made within 15 days after denial,
conditional approval, or lack of action by the Planning Zoning Board. Every decision
by Town Council shall be subject to review by the superior court by proceedings in the
nature of certiorari.
(E) Action by Town Council. If a site plan is appealed to the Town Council, it shall be
scheduled, subject to filing deadlines, to be reviewed at the next regularly scheduled
meeting.
(F) Conditional approvals. If the site plan is granted conditional approval by the Planning
Zoning Board or Town Council, the applicant shall revise and resubmit the site plan.
The Planning Department of the Enforcement Officer shall review the revised site
plan and, if it meets all the approval conditions and is otherwise substantially
unaltered, shall signify on the plan the change from conditional approval to approval.
If the site plan is not revised within 60 days to meet the approval conditions, or the
applicant notifies the Guilford County Planning Department that he is unwilling to
revise the site plan, it shall bedeemed denied.
3-12.2. - Requirements for zoning map amendments.
(A) General requirements. Any person authorized to seek an Ordinance amendment
shall submit an application according to a form provided by the Planning Department,
along with other required information pursuant to Appendix 2 (Map Standards) in
cases where sketch plans or site plans are required.
NOTE: The Town of Pleasant Garden currently contracts with Guilford County's
Planning Department, which is the entity referred to above herein.
(B) Fee. All fees shall be due and payable when the application is made according to the
schedule of fees.
(C) Filing of application.
1)
No application for rezoning to the same district shall be filed within a one-year
period from the date of final action on the previous rezoning request (other than
a withdrawal, subject to the provisions of Subsection 3-12.2(F), Application
Withdrawal, prior to the public hearing) on a givenparcel of land or portion thereof
unless the proposal is substantially different from the previous submission and
the Planning Zoning Board determines that evidence submitted to them merits
consideration for a public hearing at their next meeting.

2)
A second request for the same parcel of land or portion thereof for a different
zoning district mayoccur within a one-year period from final action on the initial
request.
3)
Under no circumstances may more than two zoning map amendments be filed
for rezoning a given parcel of land or any portion thereof within any one-year
period.
(D) Notification. The posting of signs, publishing of legal notices and other procedures as
provided in Article IX (Administration) and N.C.G.S. § 160D-602 shall be followed.
(E)
Public hearing. The Planning-Zoning Board shall hold a public hearing on the
application. The Planning Department, shall present the application to the Planning
Zoning Board, together with the Planning Department's recommendations, at the first
regularly scheduled meeting following proper filing and notice of the application.
(F) Application withdrawal.
1)
An application for amendment may be withdrawn by the applicant at any time
before submission of the public notice to the newspaper announcing the public
hearing.
2)
After submission of such notice, an application may be withdrawn at the
discretion of the Planning Zoning-Board or Town Council at the public hearing.
3)
No more than two withdrawals may occur on the same parcel of land or portion
thereof within a one-year period.
4)
No application shall be filed on the same parcel of land or portion thereof within a
one-year periodafter the date of the second withdrawal.
(G) Continuance. The Planning-Zoning Board may continue a rezoning request for up to
two months provided the reason for said continuance is stated in the motion to
continue. Nothing in this Section shall prohibit a continuance being granted for a
greater period of time provided it is mutually agreed upon by all parties concerned.
Upon failure of the Planning Zoning Board to act on a request immediately following
all proper continuances, or if no action is taken, the petitioner may take the rezoning
application to the Town Council without a recommendation from the Planning-Zoning
Board.
(H) Voting.
1)
A favorable majority vote from the Planning Zoning Board shall constitute a
favorable recommendation of the application and shall be forwarded to the
Governing Body.
2)
Applications receiving less than a majority favorable vote or unfavorable vote
from the Planning Zoning Board shall constitute an unfavorable recommendation
of the application and shall be forwardedto the Governing Body.
3)
Applications shall be scheduled for a public hearing before the Town Council.
4)
Reserved.
5)
All votes of the Planning-Zoning Board on zoning map amendments shall be
accompanied by a written statement, citing the consistency of the Town's adopted
long range plan, comprehensive plan, or any officially adopted plan. The Planning
Zoning Board will also specify that the amendment is reasonablear in the public
interest. Comment by the Planning Zoning Board that a proposed amendment is
inconsistent with the long-range plan, or any other adopted plan, shall not

preclude considerationor approval of the proposed amendment by the Governing
Body Town Council.
6)
A Planning Zoning Board member shall not vote on any zoning map amendment
where the outcome of hematter being considered is reasonably likely to have a
direct, substantial, and readily identifiable financial impact on the member, nor
vote on any zoning amendment if the landowner of the property subject to a
rezoning petition or the applicant for a text amendment is a person with whom
the member has a close familial, business, or other associational relationship.
3-12.4. - Requirements for text amendments.
(A) Submission of application. Applications to amend the text of this Ordinance shall be
submitted to the Enforcement Officer.
(B) Public hearing. The Enforcement Officer shall refer such applications to the Planning
Zoning Board which shall conduct a public hearing complying with all notice
requirements as set forth in N.C.G.S. § 160D-601.
(C) Planning Zoning Board procedure. Applications for text amendments shall be
processed, considered and votedupon in the same procedure as that required for
zoning map amendments.
(D) Planning Zoning Board recommendation. The Planning Zoning Board shall make a
recommendation to the Town Councilconcerning the proposed text amendment after
a public hearing. The Planning Zoning-Boa recommendation must be accompanied
by written findings as to the consistency of the proposed amendment to the Town's
adopted land-use plan and any other officially adopted planning document.
(E)
Application approval. The Town Council shall approve or disapprove the text
amendment after receiptof the recommendation from the Planning Zoning Board and
a public hearing. A Town Council member or appointed official may not vote on any
zoning text amendment where the outcome of the matter beingconsidered is
reasonably likely to have a direct, substantial, and readily identifiable financial impact
onthe member, nor vote on any zoning amendment if the landowner of the property
subject to a rezoning petition or the applicant for a text amendment is a person with
whom the member has a close familial, business, or other associational relationship.
3-16.2. - Approval procedures.
(A) Notice and public hearing. Notice of any proposed approval for a zoning vested
right shall be as provided in Section 9-1.2(A)4). The Planning Zoning Board shall
hold a public hearing on the matter in accordance with Section 9-2.3(A).
(B) Approval by Planning Zoning Board. The following plans shall be vested for two
years from the date of approvalby the Planning Zoning Board following notice and
public hearing by the Planning Zoning-Board:
1) A preliminary plat for a minor subdivision;
2) A plot plan;
3) Minor site plans in accordance with Section 3-11.4;
4) A master or common sign plan;
5) A watershed development plan;
6) A landscaping plan;

7) A preliminary plat for a major subdivision;
8)
A major site plan approved in accordance with Section 3-11.4 but not including
master or commonsign plans, watershed development plans or landscaping
plans; or
9) A special use permit.
4-9.1. - Minimum size.
The special-purpose lot shall be permitted only after the Planning Zoning Board
has determined that the proposed lot has sufficient dimensions to accommodate the
intended use and, where required by this Ordinance, planting yards if required per
Ordinance. Revised preliminary subdivision plats for delineating up to three off-site
sewage treatment special purpose lots may be allowed with Planning Zoning Board
approval.
4-10.1. - Historic district.
(A) Designation procedure. Historic districts, as provided for in this Section, may be
designated, amendedor repealed through the following procedure:
1)
An investigation and report describing the significance of the buildings,
structures, features, sites or surroundings included in any such proposed
district, and a description of the boundaries of such district must be prepared
by the Historic Preservation Commission and a recommendation thereon made
to the Planning Zoning Board;
2)
The North Carolina Department of Cultural Resources, acting through the State
Preservation Officer or his designee, shall make an analysis of and
recommendations concerning such report and the description of proposed
boundaries. Failure of the Department of Cultural Resources to submit its

AN ORDINANCE AMENDING THE
THE PLEASANT GARDEN DEVELOPMENT
ORDINANCE TO AMEND THE CIVIL
PENALTY ENFORCEMENT PROVISIONS
AND MAKE A TECHNICAL REVISION
WHEREAS:
It is the opinion of the Town Council that amendment of the current civil penalty
enforcement provisions of the Development Ordinance, under the authority delegated to
the Town by Chapter 160D of the North Carolina General Statutes, is warranted in order to
update the procedures therefor and make the purpose and implementation thereof clearer
and more efficient, and thereby enhance the health, safety, welfare, and property values of
the citizens of Pleasant Garden; and,
Amendment of the Development Ordinance to provide for periodic amendment or
emendation of the ordinance's non-substantive table of contents to adjust and maintain
same consistently with specific and periodically adopted substantive amendments or
emendations, and without having to specifically direct such adjustment and maintenance
of the table of contents, will enhance efficiency in the ongoing maintenance of the
Development Ordinance;
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED:
Section 1. Article I, Section 1-8.2 "Rules of Construction" of the Development Ordinance
is amended to change the title thereof to "Rules of Construction and Codification" and by
adding the following new subsection (F):
(F) Up enactment of any substantive change in this ordinance modifying the section
numbers or letters thereof, the Table of Contents of this ordinance shall be appropriately
amended or emended to be consistent with such enactment.
Section 2. Article VIII, "Enforcement" of the Pleasant Garden Development Ordinance
is rewritten to read as follows:
8-5. - CIVIL PENALTIES-ASSESSMENT AND PROCEDURES
8-5.1. Administrative action. In any instance of a violation of this chapter which
reasonably would not cause imminent peril to life or property if not enjoined, or which is
not transitory in nature, the code enforcement officer shall enforce this chapter
administratively by issuance of a notice of violation subject to G.S. 160D-302, in
accordance with the following procedure:

a. Notice of violation. When the enforcement officer or his agent determines that work
or activity has been undertaken in violation of a development regulation adopted
pursuant to this chapter or other local development regulation or any state law delegated
to the town for enforcement purposes in lieu of the state or in violation of the terms of a
development approval the code enforcement officer shall give notice of violation in
accordance with G.S. 160D-404. The notice of violation shall be delivered to the holder
of the development approval and to the landowner of the property involved, if the
landowner is not the holder of the development approval, by personal delivery,
electronic delivery, or first-class mail and may be provided by similar means to the
occupant of the property or the person undertaking the work or activity. The notice of
violation may be posted on the property. The notice shall state:
1. The nature of the violation, and citation to the section of this chapter violated;
2. The measures necessary to correct and fully abate the violation; and
3. The amount of the civil penalty that will be assessed, what day the assessment will
begin, and how long the assessment will continue and accrue, in the event the violation
is not corrected and fully abated.
b. Assessment of civil penalty. Any person or entity served with a notice of violation
under this section who fails to correct and abate fully the violation cited in the notice of
violation within 30 days of receipt of the notice of violation shall be assessed a civil
penalty beginning on the 31 st day after service of the notice of violation, for that day and
each day thereafter until the violation cited in the notice of violation has been corrected
and fully abated, in the amount of $200.00 for each day the violation continues to exist.
C. Certification of correction and demand for payment of penalty. The code enforcement
officer upon the correction and full abatement of a violation noticed under this section
shall serve upon the violator, in the same manner prescribed in this section for service
of notices of violation, a certification of correction and abatement setting forth the total
number of days the violation existed, a calculation of the total amount of civil penalties
that accrued during such period, and a demand for payment of the total amount of
accrued civil penalties within 30 days from service of the certification. If payment is not
received or equitable settlement reached within 30 days after the demand contained in
the certification is made by service of the certification on the violation, the total amount
of the civil penalties shall be collected from the violation by a civil action in the nature of
debt in the appropriate division of the general courts of justice.
8-5.1 - Penalties. Any person who violates any provisions of this Ordinance shall be
subject
to
assessment
of
a
civil
penalty
in
the
amount
of
$25.00
for
the
first
violation;
$50.00 for the second violation; $100.00 for the third violation; and $200.00 for the fourth
and succeeding violations thereafter; except that any penalties assessed shall be stayed
until
all appeals are resolved.
8-5.2. - Notice.

No civil penalty shall be assessed until the person alleged to be in violation has been
notified of the violation in accordance with Section 8-3.1 (Notice of Violation). If after
receiving a notice of violation under Section 8-3.1, the owner or other violator fails to take
corrective action, a civil penalty may be imposed under this Section in the form of a
citation. The citation shall be served in the manner of a notice of violation. The citation
shall state the nature of the violation, the civil penalty to be imposed upon the violator and
shall direct the violator to pay the civil penalty within 15 days of the date of the notice.
8-5.23. - Responsible parties.
The owner or occupant of any land, building, structure, sign, or use of land or part thereof
and any architect, builder, contractor, agent or any other person who participates or acts
in concert, assists, directs, creates, or maintains any condition that is in violation of the
requirements of this Ordinance may be held responsible for the violation and subject to
the civil penalties and remedies herein provided.
8-5.4. Continuing violation.
For each day the violation is not corrected, the violator will be guilty of an additional and
separate offense and subject to additional civil penalty.
8-5.5. Demand for payment.
The Enforcement Officer shall make written demand for payment upon the property owner
or the person in violation, and shall set forth in detail a description of the violation for
which the civil penalty has been imposed.
8-5.6. - Nonpayment.
If payment is not received or equitable settlement reached within 30 days after demand
for payment is made, the matter shall be referred to legal counsel for institution of a civil
action in the appropriate division of the General Courts of Justice for recovery of the civil
penalty. Provided, however, if the civil penalty is not paid within the time prescribed, the
Enforcement Officer may have a criminal summons or warrant issued against the violator.
Upon conviction, the violator shall be subject to any criminal penalty the court may impose
pursuant to N.C.G.S. § 14-4.
Section 3. This ordinance is effective upon adoption.

AN ORDINANCE
AMENDING THE
THE PLEASANT GARDEN DEVELOPMENT ORDINANCE
TO ADOPT DEVELOPMENT STANDARDS TO ADDRESS
THE STORAGE AND MAINTAININCE OF RECREATION
VEHICLE, CAMPERS, MOTORHOMES, BOATS, AND
WATERCRAFT
WHEREAS:
The storage and maintenance of recreation vehicles, campers, motor homes, boats, and
watercraft is a land use properly subject to zoning, under the authority granted
municipalities in Chapter 160D of the North Carolina General Statutes;
The Pleasant Garden Development Ordinance currently lacks provisions regulating such
use; and,
The Town Council is of the opinion that amendment of the Development Ordinance to
provide for such regulation will enhance the value, safety, and enjoyment of land within
the jurisdiction, by requiring the orderly storage and maintenance of such vehicles and
vessels in residential zones and thereby authorizing abatement of current and future
instances of unreasonable and inappropriate storage and maintenance thereof.
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED:
"Article VI - Development Standards" of the Pleasant Garden Development Ordinance is
hereby amended as follows:
Section 1.
Current Sec. 6-4.58 is rewritten to read as follows:
6-4.58. -Recreational vehicles and vessels.
(A)
Recreation vehicles, Campers, and Motor homes:
1) Shall be stored in a towable position when stored on a residential lot.
2) Shall be stored only on a lot containing a primary residence.
3) Shall not be hooked up to water or sewer service
4) Shall be stored at least 15 feet behind the front plane of the house or in the rear yard.
5) Shall be stored on an improved surface such as a driveway or concrete slab, and shall not
be parked on grass or other natural surfaces.
(B)
Boats and watercraft:
1) Shall be stored only on a lot containing a primary residence.
2) Shall be stored at least 15 feet behind the front plane of the house or in the rear yard.
3) Shall be stored on an improved surface such as a paved driveway or concrete slab, and
shall not be parked on grass or other natural surfaces.
4) Shall be limited to no more than three (3) boats and/or watercraft stored on any single parcel.
(C)
Recreational vehicle park: See Section 6-4.49.

Section 2. The Table of Contents of the Pleasant Garden Development Ordinance is amended
to rewrite the entry 6-4.4-58 to read "Recreational vehicles and vessels."
Section 3. This ordinance is effective upon adoption.

, 2023.
